ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] The "new media types are evil" meme
ygData.msgSnippet: Markus: ok, let me ask you directly, can you imagine any circumstance where the differences between transclusion (LE) and navigation (LO) matter in an M2M

Markus:
ok, let me ask you directly, can you imagine any circumstance where=

the differences between transclusion (LE) and navigation (LO) "matter"
in =
an M2M scenario?=A0mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
=
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me




On Tue, Jan 10, 2012 at 01:39, Markus Lan=
thaler
<markus.lanthaler@...> wrote:
>> while i used HTML in some examp=
les, the idea of transclusion and
>> navigation are not limited to visual a=
ffordances. i cited x:include as
>> one example and could have using LINK, =
X:LINK, etc. in others. in an
>> M2M scenario i have in mind (a real life e=
xample, btw), a set of
>> machines make requests of a server in order to ge=
t "work" to complete
>> (in this case documents and/or images to process in=
 various ways as
>> indicated by data returned by the servers). these bots =
recognize (in
>> one case) affordances that instruct the client to gather o=
ther data
>> from other locations in order to complete a single document th=
at is to
>> be sent to the server for additional work. in another case, the=
 client
>> recognizes affordances that instruct the client to go evaluate t=
he
>> current state of the resource, select optimal values and submit them
=
>> to one or more servers for additional processing. and so forth.
>
> This=
 all sounds good but why should it matter if it's a link or an embed if
> i=
t's not rendered to a human user? The client nevertheless has to understand=

> what to do with that specific resource in order to reach its goal - whet=
her
> it's LE or LO doesn't really matter IMO. Or am I wrong?
>
>
>> if i u=
nderstand you, you are making a case for representations that
>> indicate v=
ariance in what selections clients have; what action they
>> can take. this=
 _seems_ to be at odds w/ what peter indicated to me in
>> his reply.
>> <s=
nip>We have the uniform interface so any method may be called on any
>> res=
ource.</snip>
>> do you think i am mis-representing peter's reply here?
>
>=
 I think so. I think Peter was referring to HTTP methods which are uniform
=
> and available on all resource. Nevertheless those methods might not be
> =
supported and/or allowed for certain resources (at certain times).
>
>
>> l=
et's steer clear of "meaning" and "learn" here. i am not making any
>> clai=
ms or requirements of this type. =A0what i have stated to this point
>> is =
that there are two types of _information_ i am interested in
>> including i=
n messages sent from server to client: protocol-level
>> information and do=
main-specific information. I have given examples of
>> protocol-level infor=
mation that i can include in message designs. i
>> have asserted that i am =
unable to clearly indicate that same level of
>> protocol information when =
using RDF-based media types. am i incorrect?
>
> That question here that ar=
ises for me is if you can really separate it that
> way!? Protocol level in=
formation is in my opinion in most cases quite
> tightly coupled to the dom=
ain-specific information, i.e., the application
> domain. In HTML e.g. it's=
 hypertext documents and there it surely makes
> sense to have general hype=
rlinks and forms. In RDF you are talking about raw
> data which is interlin=
ked. Since the way of presenting this data is entirely
> up to the client I=
 doubt that a "form" is an adequate abstraction.
>
>
>> i also concede that=
 you and Peter question whether the protocol-level
>> information i have id=
entified is _needed_ in messages from servers.
>> Peter states:
>> "I am no=
t sure why protocol method is important. "
>> and
>> "Why would a media typ=
e need to encode [idempotency] information?"
>>
>> And you say:
>> "The dif=
ference between LO and LE ... just matters if a human being is
>> looking a=
t a rendered representation of the data "
>> and
>> "[templates are] part o=
f the presentational logic which is unimportant
>> in M2M scenarios."
>
> I=
 don't question whether they are needed but whether it makes sense to
> sep=
arate them from the domain specific information. A MIME type is
> specifyin=
g a format for a more or less specific application domain. That
> MIME type=
 also specifies how the protocol-level information has to be
> interpreted =
so I'm not sure if you can really separate them in the way you
> propose (a=
s I understand it). IOW for me both are at the same level of
> abstraction.=

>
>
>> >> - IME, transclusion is not exclusively a H2M (human-to-machine)
=
>> >> affordance, i use "x:include" quite often in M2M cases
>> >
>> > Hmm.=
.. Could you elaborate a bit on this? Why don't you simply
>> include it,
>=
> > i.e., merge it into the response instead of just linking to it?
>>
>> i=
 think the scenario i cited at the top of this reply answers to this
>> poi=
nt.
>
> I still don't really understand the difference. It is up to the dom=
ain
> semantics what the client does. Whether the protocol-level informatio=
n says
> embed or link doesn't make any difference IMHO. But maybe you are =
more
> thinking of splitting the semantics into two parts which are: embed =
(the
> client *has* to follow this link) + process it according the remaini=
ng
> domain semantics!?
>
>
>> in the implementations i create, not all pos=
sible variables are
>> acceptable in call cases, even if all variables are =
_known_
>> beforehand. in my work clients look in the message to see which =
of the
>> client's known variables are valid for this instance and (in some=

>> cases) which are required/optional. there is even at least one case
>> =
where variables are group--dependent (if you supply x you MUST supply
>> x,=
 etc.). these are time/instance dependent cases.
>
> I don't see why this s=
hould be a problem..
>
>
>> i program clients as state machines to be able =
to recognize
>> affordances and respond to them. some are quitre simple (im=
mutable
>> links for navigation). others are more involved (mutable templat=
es for
>> completing request bodies, URI templates, choices of one or more =
"next
>> steps" evaulated against a goal or other workflow of the client,
>=
> etc.).
>>
>> the work i do right now is not a fixed set of =A0actions w/ =
static,
>> pre-defined parameters. knowing a set of static state transition=
s
>> ahead of time is insufficient for this work. instead clients need to
>=
> be prepared to respond to representations returned by the server.
>
> May=
be you misunderstood me slightly here. All I wanted to say is that it
> doe=
sn't matter whether your client looks for a link with rel=3D"payment" or a
=
> JSON property "payment": "URI". It's just a different syntax, that's all.=
.
>
>
>> > But I agree, there is a need for a small and simple vocabulary t=
o
>> describe
>> > basic control flows - something I planned to work on rat=
her sooner
>> than
>> > later.
>>
>> i look forward to hearing more on this=
.
>
> If I just would have a bit more time :-(
>
>
>
> --
> Markus Lanthale=
r
> @markuslanthaler
>
